results.title: Voyage a travers l'impossible
results.brief_description: Across mountains, under the sea and into the sun, a group of strange travellers attempt an impossible voyage. Exploiting Melies’ mastery of film magic, this early cinema classic explores a vast range of fantasy landscapes. The travellers breach space and time as they travel, using every imaginable means of transportation, from one space and place to another in the attempt to geographically explore the earth and the surrounding space. This extraordinary science fiction fantasy was only one of the many pioneering films made by Melies in the early 1900s and it, like his other films, combines whimsical humour with wild imaginative journeys.

group_siblings.title: Le Voyage dans la Lune (A Trip to the Moon)
L'Eclipse du Soleil en Pleine Lune

results.title: L'Eclipse du Soleil en Pleine Lune
results.brief_description: An aging astronomer invites students to his castle observatory to observe a solar eclipse. Amid the childish pranks of the novice astronomers and the wondrous vision of the eclipse, George Melies, cinema’s great magician, weaves numerous amusing set pieces. Much to the astronomer’s excitement, the sun and the moon flirt with each other as they come together in an astronomical courtship and the sky explodes in a dance of female stars. On earth, the astronomer falls prey to his cheeky students who rob him of his stately dignity, while the heavens smile down on him from above.

results.title: Outer space
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and audio
results.brief_description: Prolific Austrian avant-garde filmmaker and theorist, Peter Tscherkassky, reinvents a 1981 Barbara Hershey horror vehicle, leaving the original’s crystalline surface intact only to violently shatter its narrative illusion. Sounds of crickets, static and distorted music give way to explosions, screams, and garbled voices. The actress’ face multiplies across the screen as the frame is invaded by sprocket holes, an optical soundtrack, and flashes of solarized imagery.
